comment:
too frenetic, leaving me feeling like I can't control my fate well enough,

And the El Grande is the biggest waste of a game component.

Bounced off this one, hard. Just too much chaos for me to enjoy. For something similar with a little more excitement and shorter play time, look at Condottiere.
– For a cube pusher the tempo is slow with lots of downtime. There is the understanding the cards stage, figuring out how the cards intersect with the board state, then blind bidding for turn order, then action phase. Repeat, repeat. A 5p 3 hour game of this would be torture.
– Kingmaking is huge in this game. Unless everyone is playing to some sort of agreed code and has some game skill.
– Hidden trackable information. Not a problem for me but some players hate this.
– Super tactical game and there will be a lot of bash the leader, given it is not always obvious who is in front this leads back to king making and a general feeling of total chaos.
Was way more abstract than all the hype led me to believe. There's a lot of chaos, but it feels like most of that is injected by the special cards, rather than the system itself.
Terrible game
Too old. Don't believe everyone who says that it still relevant.

Did nothing for me. There are some interesting mechanisms but overall, this game just wasn't stimulating enough. It is probably between a 2 and 3 for me; but I need to account for the hype before playing the game, and the disappointment that followed upon playing it.

It felt monotonous, definitely has issues with kingmaking, and suffers from too much downtime. HBTI serves as the icing on the cake. Definition of obsolescence. There were times during the game where I would have rather watched grass grow; far more interesting.

There's 3 hours I'm never getting back.

Area control is a mechanic that appeals to me when I play games like Louis XIV, Struggle of Empires, and Age of Empires III. However, those games involve the development of infrastructure or additional mechanics like worker placement; by comparison, El Grande is an exercise in pure tactical area control. What I find occurs in such games is that players place their influence or use screw-your-neighbor opportunities to keep everyone else in check and the guy picked on least by his opponents will win.

After a few scorings someone is out in front, and players must bash the leader because if unhindered he will maintain first place and ultimately win. Put another way, when a player gets an opportunity that scores him extra points, in all likelihood the action is actually worthless because he will lose points later that he otherwise would have scored because his opponents are obligated to target him. If this process is performed effectively, players' scores will remain within a small range, and big plays around the third scoring will decide the game.

El Grande's excessively tactical nature has other issues. The value of a Mobile Scoring tile varies wildly depending on whether the other two copies of it are lurking right below. A typical plan to drop '13' and have the last word on the King's whereabouts can be arbitrarily thwarted by Royal Advisor. Decay of Authority is extremely nasty and fear of the card nullifies an actual strategy like playing 1-3 within the first half of the game to enable 10-13 for the second half. Turn order introduces problems as well; many turns nobody selects the 1-stack, screw-your-neighbor actions because of the restriction on piece placement but when a player is dropping '1' this turn no matter what to prepare for next turn's pre-scoring '13' he'll often be stuck picking between the 1-stack or some crappy 2-stack card so he'll take the screw-your-neighbor - a completely situational shaft if you happen to be that neighbor encroaching on what he considers his turf.

One play was way more than enough for me. As bad as Puerto Rico, Hansa Teutonica, et al. Classic example with what is wrong with so many Euros. Why do Euro designers feel that dry, abstract mechanics, analysis paralysis and pasted on theme make a fun game. Throw in that once you fall behind, you are essentially out of the game. THIS IS NOT FUN AT ALL! Attention Euro designers, games are meant to be fun, not just interesting. Games like these will always be inaccessible and prevent our hobby from growing.

What I like:
- One of the first area majority games.
- Castillo offers a nice element of surprise.

What I dislike:
- Too chaotic, too long, too much down time without anything to think about since the board state will usually change so much. This is mainly due to the special action cards that add lots of randomness and are very tactical.

Time to revisit the comment.

Or why I like area majority, but not El Grande.

Basically - everything El Grande does wrong, CitoW does right.
1. No idiotic turn order auction. Seems like a thing that was antiquated in 1995. Plus the whole units to court to board nonsense. Ugh. CitoW corrects this by Khorne goes first because He Is The Blood God, now shutup! Dominant Species corrects this by - worker placement space for becoming first player.
2. Adjacency matters in CitoW - you can move to areas next to your areas. In 16th century Spain however cabelleros can teleport all over the map, but only in areas next to king, but not where the king which represents historic situation of who the hell knows.
3. 16th c. Ibiza paratroopers. Huh?
4. The action cards - no theme to it, so you have to memorise them. Also their effect are tactical and unpredictable, so there's lots of AP and downtime. CitoW and DS solved this more elegantly (in Citow each god has their own deck and a hand of cards, DS - bidding for cards is part of a long phase so the card effects can be mitigated).

Later Kramers are better as well - Mexica and Torres - No turn order nonsense, cards in Torres are simpler and the spacial relations make much more sense making the whole thing is more intuitive to grasp.

Hmmm...let's see...is it the cube pushing that I hate? Or is it the expansion of 1 pissing contest into 12 pissing contests? Or is it the bash-the-leader that ires me? Or perhaps it is the droll card auction mechanic? Or maybe it is the 100% tactical gameplay? I just can't decide which part of this turd is brownest...it is very brown though. The cubes are bright colors. I think that must be what draws people to it. It plays like a game for people with no memory or attention span. Each round would be exactly the same if you just randomly set it up and asked each player to evaluate the game state and make the least sub-optimal choice. So this is fun then? Look at me, I'm having fun...

Didn't like this -- just wasn't very much fun. Don't know why this is called a strategy game. Due to the amount of chaos/changes that go on between turns, this is entirely a tactical exercise with little ability to make and carry out long term plans. On top of that, it is slow to play with lots of downtime as others ponder their changed situations. I'm willing to give it another try before writing it off completely, but I'm very skeptical that my rating will improve.

Action cards have the potential to be crazy powerful. Makes this feel a little like area majorities with a significant lean in the direction of crazy card powers. It’s fine, can certainly be dramatic near the top. Definitely possible to be out of contention by the end of the first scoring on the bottom end, though. The final three rounds have so many cubes on the board and such potential for huge swings with the action cards that there is a serious potential for AP to really bog this down.

Ultimately i find it pretty dry and unexciting, but I can see that there's a good game here. Wouldn't choose it over other titles, but wouldn't be particularly opposed to playing it.

Mogul Scale: 2/C.
Very old school area control game.

Players try to score points by having the most workers on different areas on the map. However workers can only be deployed adjacent to the king (not in the same region as the king). Players can also put workers in the castle, which gets opened at the end of a round and deployed to a certain region (only the player with the most workers deploys those units). At the start of each round players take turns selecting powerful actions such as moving the king, changing the points scored on each region

bga win

A classic for good reason. Recent games have felt a little flat, however.

Particular kudos to the recent reprint - being excellent in terms of quality and aesthetics, while also being responsibly produced. An exemplary example of how to do it by Hans im Glück.

The players’ actions lack any meaningful connection to the setting or narrative. The core concept or story that underpins the gaming experience is weak. The game’s mechanisms and rules are disconnected from the setting or theme. In other words, the game feels out of sync and neither cohesive nor immersive.

Additionally, the flow of the game is somewhat clumsy, with elements that don’t quite fit together. The concept of auctions for turn order, the division of the three game zones—province, court, and map—the restrictions on placing and moving the caballeros, and the fact that successful play depends on memorizing the different card decks are all examples of how the game feels a bit disjointed.

It also perplexes me that there still isn't a proper edition of this classic. The old edition looks like cauliflower, and the latest version is a pastel-colored disaster. While I can tolerate the meeples, even if their shape offers no clear advantage over cubes, the map’s colors are a different matter. They are overly bold and, in some cases, even match the player colors, making it difficult to distinguish the pieces: green figures on a green background, red figures on a red background, and so on. It feels as though the map was designed based on market research by an AI with no real understanding of board game design.

What sets it apart is its accessibility and the high level of player interaction. El Grande has a distinct advantage in that it’s easy to pick up and play, it’s relatively straightforward with clear goals — which I also find increasingly valuable as time goes on.

6/10: dudes on a map, pretty pure area control game. Draft from a set of cards(there needs to be more options for me to play this more than 5 times without becoming bored.).

I really enjoy the keep (?) mechanic of dropping guys in and being able to deploy them at the end. I’m truly terrible at predicting what people are going to do but it’s fun!

Im no good at these and they often create an intensity that is simply too much for me. I don’t like how these games make me feel.

But with the right group, knowing it’s gonna push me, I can enjoy this and make sillier moves while still trying to win.

El Grande takes a simple core mechanic and puts it in medieval Spain, though the theme and aesthetic are somewhat bland.
The game presents you with interesting trade-offs in terms of acting earlier or later in the round, and which regions you want to compete for. Unfortunately, the action cards you are choosing from are often uninspiring... The king-moving card brings a lot of game, but a lot of other cards just fall short, including a lot of duplicates. In the version I've played, the text on some cards is actually incomplete, and you have to look for the full text in the rules.
To conclude, El Grande is a game I can have fun playing, but it's not one I'll be suggesting to bring to the table.

There is a lot I like about El Grande. The turn order bid is wonderful, as is the variety of effects that will turn up. It's a very economical design that explores its few mechanisms fully without becoming overbearing or cumbersome.

Despite all of that, I just do not find the gameplay compelling enough to make up for the near absence of narrative or humor. Creativity and self expression are punished, and the game starts to give the familiar euro experience of trying to do the same thing as everyone else, but better. I simply do not find these sorts of games interesting.

For a hot take: this would be better with player elimination, such as in Age of Steam or Ankh.

Good for it's time, but I consider it to have player rubber banding, 'cause the last player just takes the least popular turn, which is still good. There's only 5 cards you can select each turn. So it's like a pathway game.
This game needs more players than we can bring to the table. It's just not great at two.

It's unfortunate that the term "classic" is too often applied to the forgettable and the mediocre. That El Grande, published in the twilight of the 20th century, continues not only to endure but to command reverence, is a welcome exception.

This is a game that dispenses with the superfluous. There are no dice here to absolve you of poor judgment, no novelties to distract from one central fact: you are wielding power. Not an anemic simulacrum of power offered by lesser designs, but a raw contest for dominance over a disunited Spain, where every move is a deliberate calculation, and, if you're playing well, an act of subterfuge.

What distinguishes and elevates El Grande is that it demands from you what all worthy games demand: attentiveness, adaptability, and above all, an understanding of timing. The game is won not by the accumulation of power alone, but by its judicious deployment. It trusts you to think, to plan, to manoeuvre. To assert your will. And that is rare enough in this age of incessant gratification and gaudy design.

In short, it is a triumph of form and function; a reminder that sophistication in design requires the courage to do less and say more. The ghost of Philip II might well look on approvingly.
L'ancêtre du jeu de majorité ! Exceptionnel !
Deserved the fame. Easier than what they say and ioncredibly approachable.

Masterpiece.

It's incredible how a game from 1995 can deliver such a clean, elegant and fun experience.

You can teach El Grande in 10 minutes to anyone, then you got yourself right into a deep, tight experience with a highly cutthroat interaction. Yes, it can be swingy and yes, there can be a lot of "bashing the leader" if someone start to run forward but hey, don't make yourself too many enemies too fast 

5p is the ideal player count but you can enjoy it a lot also on 4p and still playing at 3p with some an easy variant which combines two of the decks.

I think most of newer area majority games are just harder to learn, play less smoothly and only have big and good looking miniatures.

I played the first German edition at Play Fair in Italy and suddenly bought the same version on second hand market for less than 20 bucks. Don't get yourself fooled by the simple and old looking board, if you like highly interactive, easy to learn but deep games, El Grande will be a bust!

Prime area-majority, with clean, direct mechanics and really fun components (basically, referring to just the Castillo). There's a lot of good interaction and a lot of variability, both good signs for a Euro. El Grande is a worthy classic.

I own the Decennial Edition.

Brilliant game…easy to learn, heavily interactive, tense from beginning to end. Lots of trying to get into the heads of other players. The mechanics are straightforward but interwoven in a very clever way.
The first few plays felt very chaotic, but now I realize that there’s more long-term strategy than first meets the eye. There is some randomness in the card draw that can spoil one’s plans, but an experienced player can hedge against these events by getting their caballeros out early and carefully distributing them across the board. Knowing the cards (especially the “score immediately” ones in stack 3) is essential to determining where to put your caballeros.
I will also say that the 4 player game is just as good as the 5 player game; although it doesn’t feel quite as tight, it plays quicker and is less chaotic, thanks to the Intrigue cards mostly going unplayed.

In my opinion, this is a modern classic. It’s a simple area control game with a surprising amount of strategy. Each game feels different and is highly interactive, which is exactly what I look for. Easy to learn but hard to master, it offers incredible replayability and interaction.
Love it so far. Needs many more plays!
